choices.text: Start breastfeeding as early as possible
Cover the baby's head and body
Bathe the baby with warm water
Clear eyes with a sterile swab

questions.text: A mother delivers in a rural area under the guidance of a skilled care attendant. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the care provided by the skilled care attendant at birth?
questions.solution:
Immediate bathing can lead to hypothermia and is discouraged right after birth. Instead, the focus should be on keeping the baby warm and starting breastfeeding.

Antenatal Care and Skilled Attendance at Birth by ANMs/LHVs/SNs:

  • The Government of India, under its National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) and Reproductive and Child Health (RCH)-II program, is committed to ensuring that all births are attended by skilled healthcare professionals.
  • This applies to both healthcare facilities and community settings.
  • The aim is to provide easy access to emergency care for mothers and newborns, reducing the number of maternal and newborn deaths in the country.

Newborn care by ASHA/skilled care attendant:

  • Place the baby on the mother's abdomen.
  • Look for meconium. If there is none, proceed to dry the baby with a warm towel or piece of clean cloth. (Do not wipe off the white greasy substance (vernix) covering the baby's body. Vernix helps to protect the baby's skin.)
  • Breastfeeding is to be started as soon as possible after delivery, preferably within 1 hour after birth. (Option A ruled out)
  • Wrap the newborn with blanket/sheet; ensure to cover the head as well. (Option B ruled out)
  • Avoid bathing the baby on the first day. Delay further on winter days. For small babies delay bathing till the cord falls off. (Option C)
  • Wipe both the eyes (separately) with sterile gauze. (Option D ruled out)

Reference:

  1. https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/sba_guidelines_for_skilled_attendance_at_birth.pdf
  2. https://nihfw.ac.in/Doc/Flipchart%20for%20ASHA.pdf

questions.text: A fruit farmer presents with fever, breathing difficulties and neurological complications. He gives history of spotting few bats in his farm. What is the most liekly diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus that fruit farmers are particularly at risk of contracting due to its association with fruit bats.
  • It presents with fever, respiratory difficulties, and severe neurological complications, including encephalitis, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Ebola (Option A): Ebola virus primarily causes hemorrhagic fever with symptoms like severe bleeding, multi-organ failure, and shock. While it can present with fever and some neurological complications, respiratory symptoms are not typical, and there is no specific association with fruit farming.

Meningitis (Option B): It causes inflammation of the meninges surrounding the brain and spinal cord, leading to fever, headache, neck stiffness, and neurological complications. However, respiratory symptoms are uncommon, and the condition is not linked to fruit farming.

Zika (Option D): Zika virus primarily causes mild symptoms like fever, rash, and joint pain, and is more famous for its complications during pregnancy, such as microcephaly in newborns. It does not commonly cause severe respiratory or neurological issues, nor is it specifically associated with fruit farming.

Reference:

  1. Ebola Virus Disease - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  2. Nipah Virus - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A group of 80 people was studied to assess the effect of diet modification on mean cholesterol levels before and after the intervention. Which statistical test is most appropriate to compare the mean cholesterol levels before and after the diet modification?
questions.solution:
• The paired t-test is the most appropriate test for comparing the mean cholesterol levels before and after diet modification in the same group of individuals.
  • This test accounts for the fact that the data are paired (pre- and post-diet modification) and assesses whether the mean difference is statistically significant.



Reference:

https://www.wjpmr.com/download/article/120032024/1711972240.pdf

questions.text: A statistician wants to study the effects of medicine in three groups: humans, animals, and plants. He selects randomly out of these three groups. Which type of sampling is performed here?
questions.solution:
• Stratified Random Sampling is the method used in this study. The statistician divides the population into three groups: humans, animals, and plants; and then selects random samples from each subgroup.
  • This approach ensures that all the three groups are appropriately represented in the study, allowing for effective study of the effects of medicine in three groups.

Simple Random Sampling (Option A): This method involves selecting individuals randomly from the entire population without considering any subgroups. In this scenario, simple random sampling would mean choosing any individual from the combined groups of humans, animals, and plants without distinguishing between them.

Systematic Sampling (Option B): This method involves selecting samples based on a fixed, periodic interval (e.g., every 10th individual). Systematic sampling is not described in this scenario since the selection process does not involve intervals or systematic patterns.

Cluster Sampling (Option D): This method involves dividing the population into clusters (groups) and then randomly selecting entire clusters for the study. The focus here is on the whole clusters rather than individual strata within those clusters.

Reference: Pubmed

questions.text: The following instrument is used for the measurement of?
questions.solution: The image given shows a Kata thermometer identified by the narrow and thin red coloured bulb. It is used to measure low air velocity and cooling power of air.

questions.text:
Which phases of the disaster cycle can be included in the recovery phase (multiple choice)?
1. Response
2. Rehabilitation
3. Mitigation
4. Preparedness
questions.solution:
Disaster management is a systematic approach using decisions, organizations to implement policies, strategies to lessen the impact of natural or man-made hazards.

Disaster management cycle:


The three fundamental aspects of disaster management:

  1. Disaster impact: Involves disaster response and relief.
  2. Disaster preparedness: It is the proper equipment of the country to manage disasters.
  3. Disaster mitigation: Preventing the hazard from becoming a disaster.

questions.text: If the incubation period of a disease is 5-14 days, what should be the recommended quarantine period?
questions.solution:
• The quarantine period is determined based on the maximum incubation period of the disease.
  • For a disease with an incubation period of 5-14 days, the longest possible incubation period is 14 days.
  • Quarantining individuals for 14 days ensures that if they were exposed to the infectious agent, symptoms would develop within this timeframe if they were infected.

Incubation period:

  • It is the time between the invasion by an infectious agent and the appearance of the first symptom.
  • During the incubation period, the infectious agent multiplies within the host.
  • Once the agent reaches a sufficient density, it disrupts the host's health equilibrium, leading to overt disease.

The median incubation period is when 50% of cases occur following exposure.

questions.text: The period between the entry of an organism into the host and the time when the host becomes maximally infectious is referred to as?
questions.solution:
This refers to the time interval between the entry of the organism into the host and the point when the host becomes infectious. It represents the period when the organism multiplies and the host can spread the infection.

Incubation Period:

  • The incubation period refers to the time it takes for an individual to develop symptoms after being infected with a pathogen.
  • It begins with exposure to the pathogen and ends with the appearance of recognisable symptoms.

Window Period: (Option C ruled out)

  • The window period is the time between infection and when the infection can be reliably detected by diagnostic tests.
  • The individual may be infectious during this period, but tests might not yet show positive results.
  • This concept is important in screening and testing strategies for infectious diseases.

Generation Time: (Option A)

  • Generation time refers to the interval of time between the recipient of the infection by the host and the maximal infectivity of that host.
  • It encompasses the entire cycle of infection, transmission, and symptom onset in the context of disease spread.

Median incubation period: (Option B ruled out)

  • The median incubation period is the time for 50% of cases to show symptoms after exposure.

questions.text: Calculate the median of the following data set: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8.
questions.solution:
The median is the middle value of an ordered data set. Since there are 8 numbers, the median is the average of the 4th and 5th numbers (4 and 5). Thus, the median is (4+5)/2 = 4.5.

The median is calculated by arranging the variables in ascending order and taking up the middle value.

This applies when an odd number of variables are given, which is given by


The median is given for variables in even numbers by averaging the two middle variables.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is kept at the lowest level?
questions.solution:
Compared to the other vaccines listed, the OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) is kept at the lowest level in Intermediate-Level Refrigerators (ILRs).




Rota (Rotavirus Vaccine) (Option D): The Rotavirus vaccine is sensitive to temperature fluctuations and is generally stored in ILRs at 2°C to 8°C. However, it is often kept at a higher level in the cold chain to ensure stability.

questions.text:
Arrange the following stages of the demographic cycle in the correct order:
1. Early expanding
2. High stationary
3. Late expanding
4. Low stationary
questions.solution: According to the demographictransition model, a country goes through 5 phases.

questions.text: In which phase of clinical trials is drug dosing determined?
questions.solution:
• Phase 1 focuses on evaluating the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of a drug in a small group of healthy volunteers or patients.
  • The primary goal is to determine the drug's safety profile and establish an appropriate dose range.
  • Dosing is initially determined based on preclinical data and adjusted as necessary based on observed effects and tolerability in this phase.

Phases of clinical trials:

questions.text: Research is being conducted to find the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer in workers who have worked in the industry for >20 years. Two groups were formed: one directly involved with dye handling and the other group consisting of office clerks not directly exposed to the dye. Years of occupation were noted from records. What type of study is being performed?
questions.solution:
• A retrospective cohort study is a combination of a prospective cohort study and a case-control study.
  • The researcher goes back in time and selects study groups from existing past medical records and traces it forward.
  • In this case, past records of the aniline dye handlers were noted to study the close association with bladder cancer.

Retrospective Cohort Study

  • Start study at present time
  • Move backwards (retrospectively) and use historical data
  • Based on historical data, divide study participants into exposed and non exposed groups.
  • Ex: Based on Medical college register of 2010 divide students into exposed and non exposed groups
  • Determine outcomes (diseased and non diseased rates) at the time study begins.
  • They produce faster results than prospective cohort studies.
  • It has been used for the study of lung carcinoma in uranium miners, arsenic in carcinogenesis, angiosarcoma of the liver, and radiation exposure in physicians.

Prospective cohort study (Option B):

  • In this study, the disease has not yet occurred when the investigation has started.
  • The investigation starts from the present and proceeds to the future.
  • A few examples are study on smoking and lung cancer, study of oral contraceptives and health.

Case-control study (Option C):

  • It starts with the disease and, hence it proceeds from effect to cause.
  • Quicker results are noticed.
  • It is suitable for the study of rare diseases and is relatively cheap.

Intervention and response (Option D):

  • It is also called an experimental study.
  • Intervention and response involves direct control over study, unlike cohort studies which are observational.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female comes to the STI clinic with minimal vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, erosions are seen on the cervix. Which of the following kit should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
• The probable diagnosis would be a sexually transmitted infection.
  • There are 7 color-coded STD kits.
  • Kit 1- Grey is given for urethral discharge, cervicitis, and anorectal discharge.

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine

questions.text: What would be the most appropriate approach to managing a young male patient who has presented at the hospital with a clean-cut wound that is not bleeding, and who received a complete tetanus vaccination 10 years ago?
questions.solution:
• Single-dose tetanus toxoid needed for clean cut wound with previous booster within 10 years
  • Thorough wound cleaning advised, removal of foreign bodies

choices.text: Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.text: A 35-year-old homeless man presented with a 1-month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Both sputum smears turned out to be negative, but the chest x-ray ordered was suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management?
questions.solution:
• According to the NTEP guidelines, a negative smear with positive chest X-ray findings would require a CBNAAT.
  • It is the current gold standard for diagnosis of tuberculosis within 90 minutes.

Repeat sputum smears (Option A): Previously it was done but not done after 2016. Repeat sputum smears are taken to monitor the treatment response.

Ask for line probe assay (Option C): Line probe assay is usually used for the diagnosis of the first line antitubercular drug resistance tuberculosis and are not indicated in this case scenario.

Wait until TB culture results to start ATT (Option D): Since it is slow growth, it takes around 4 weeks to get the sputum culture reports. Hence, it is not ideal to depend on culture reports to start ATT.

questions.text: The average life expectancy for a woman in Japan is 87 years. Due to recent advances in testing for cervical cancer, there is an increase in life expectancy by 15 years. The healthcare utility value is 0.8. Which of the following can be calculated from the parameters given?
questions.solution:
QALY (Quality-Adjusted Life Year) is calculated using life expectancy, healthcare utility values, and quality of life measures.

  • Formula: QALY = Additional Life Years × Utility Value
  • Additional Life Years = Life expectancy with intervention - Life expectancy without intervention
  • Additional life expectancy = 15 years
  • Utility value = 0.8
    • Thus, QALY = 15 × 0.8 = 12 QALYs.

HALE (Health-Adjusted Life Expectancy) (option A): HALE adjusts life expectancy by subtracting years of poor health based on population health data. The problem does not provide detailed morbidity or population health metrics necessary to calculate HALE.

DALY (Disability-Adjusted Life Year) (option B): DALY measures the burden of disease by summing years of life lost (YLL) due to premature death and years lived with disability (YLD). The parameters do not include data about years of disability or disease burden, making DALY calculation impossible.

DFLE (Disability-Free Life Expectancy) (option C): DFLE estimates the number of years a person can live without disability. No information on disability or its absence is provided, so DFLE cannot be calculated.

choices.text: Green tea reduces the risk of diabetes
Green tea increases the risk of diabetes
Data insufficient to establish causal association
The value (0.85) tends to be close to 1, hence there is no effect

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the findings of a cohort study examining the impact of green tea consumption on diabetes mellitus risk? The study revealed a risk ratio of 0.84 between drinkers and non-drinkers of green tea.
questions.solution:
Green tea reduces the risk of diabetes: A risk ratio (RR) of 0.84 indicates that the group consuming green tea has a 16% lower risk of developing diabetes compared to non-drinkers (1 - 0.84 = 0.16 or 16%). Since the RR is less than 1, it suggests a protective effect of green tea against diabetes.

Green tea increases the risk of diabetes (option B): An RR greater than 1 would indicate an increased risk. Here, the RR is less than 1, showing a reduced risk, so this option is incorrect.

Data insufficient to establish causal association (option C): While cohort studies cannot definitively establish causality (like a randomised controlled trial would), the data from this study clearly shows an association between green tea consumption and reduced diabetes risk.

The value (0.85) tends to be close to 1, hence there is no effect (option D): Though 0.84 is close to 1, it still indicates a significant reduction in risk (16%), which is not negligible. Hence, this statement is incorrect.

questions.text: Which vaccine is administered as part of the immunization program for a 10- year-old student in school?
questions.solution:
According to the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) of India, children at the age of 10 years receive the Td vaccine (Tetanus and Diphtheria, previously TT). This booster dose maintains immunity provided by earlier doses given during infancy and early childhood.

DPT (Option D): Used for children below 7 years. Beyond this age, the Td vaccine replaces DPT to minimize side effects from higher diphtheria toxoid content.

Reference:

  1. https://www.pmc.gov.in/en/NIS-for-Infants-Children-and-Pregnant-Women
  2. https://mohfw.gov.in/sites/default/files/41016395871489662752.pdf

questions.text: Which entity is responsible for overseeing the school health programs?
questions.solution:
Primary health centers (PHCs) are primarily responsible for overseeing and implementing school health programs.

They conduct regular health check-ups, immunizations, and health education in schools, ensuring the overall health and well-being of students.

questions.text: A pregnant woman whose niece lives with her in the same house contracted Varicella. She tested negative for serum antibodies against varicella. What would this mean?
questions.solution:
• Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) causes chickenpox (primary infection) and herpes zoster (reactivation).
  • Serum antibodies against VZV indicate prior infection or vaccination.
  • A negative antibody test means she has never had chickenpox nor been vaccinated, making her susceptible to primary varicella infection (chickenpox).
  • This is particularly concerning in pregnancy, as maternal varicella can lead to congenital varicella syndrome or severe neonatal infection.

She is immune to zoster (Option A): Incorrect because her negative antibody test means she has never had VZV, so reactivation as zoster is not possible.

She is susceptible to zoster (Option B): Incorrect because zoster occurs due to reactivation of prior VZV infection, which she has never had.

She is immune to chickenpox (Option D): Incorrect because a negative antibody test indicates no immunity to VZV.

questions.text: In the case of a child presenting with pharyngitis, when a throat swab is collected and sent for culture, in which colored bin should the used swab be disposed of?
questions.solution:
• In healthcare settings, waste disposal is categorized by color-coded bins to ensure safe and proper handling of different types of waste.
  • Yellow bins are typically used for disposing of clinical waste that is contaminated or potentially infectious, such as used swabs, tissues, or any material that has come into contact with body fluids.
  • In the case of a throat swab collected for culture, it would be considered infectious waste until proven otherwise, so it should be disposed of in a yellow bin.

questions.text: In a population study, if the mean value is 200 and the standard deviation is 20, what percentage of the population will fall within one standard deviation of the mean?
questions.solution:
• In a normal distribution, approximately 68% of the data falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
  • Given that the mean is 200 and the standard deviation is 20, we can calculate the range within which 68% of the population will lie.
  • One standard deviation below the mean is 200 - 20 = 180. One standard deviation above the mean is 200 + 20 = 220.
  • Therefore, approximately 68% of the population will lie between 180 and 220.

questions.text: What type of study is it when a person collects data on lung cancer patients from government hospitals and the corresponding number of cigarette packets sold during the same time period, in order to examine the relationship between smoking and lung cancer?
questions.solution:
• Ecological study examines relationship between variables at population level, not individual level.
  • Collects data on lung cancer cases and cigarette packet sales over specific time period.
  • Analyzes associations using aggregate data, providing insights into population-level relationships.
  • Doesn't establish causation or provide individual-level associations.

Incorrect Options:

Cross sectional (Option A): A cross-sectional study assesses the prevalence of variables in individuals at a specific point in time, not the relationship between variables over time.

Experimental (Option C): Experimental study involves manipulation of variables and random assignment to determine causation, not applicable here.

Quasi-experimental (Option D): Quasi-experimental study involves manipulation of variables without random assignment, also not applicable here.

choices.text: A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period
A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier
A person who acquired pathogen from patient
A patient who became a carrier

questions.text: A paradoxical carrier is defined as:
questions.solution:
A paradoxical carrier is defined as a carrier who acquired the pathogen from another carrier. This is considered "paradoxical" because, in most cases, carriers typically acquire the pathogen directly from a patient or from environmental sources. In this situation, the transmission is indirectly from a carrier.

A person who sheds pathogens during the incubation period (option A): This refers to an incubatory carrier, not a paradoxical carrier. An incubatory carrier sheds the pathogen while still in the incubation phase of the disease, before symptoms appear.

A person who acquired the pathogen from a patient (option C): This describes the typical mechanism of pathogen acquisition but does not apply to the specific definition of a paradoxical carrier.

A patient who became a carrier (option D): This describes a convalescent carrier, not a paradoxical carrier. A convalescent carrier continues to harbour and shed the pathogen after recovery from the disease.

choices.text: Green labels are for those who need to be transported on priority
Moribund patients receive the lowest priority
Most commonly used system is three color code system

questions.text: During disaster management, triage is implemented to ensure that casualties receive appropriate treatment. Which statement accurately describes the triage process conducted at the disaster site?
questions.solution:
Moribund patients, who are unlikely to survive even with treatment, are given the lowest priority during disaster triage. This ensures that limited medical resources are allocated to those who have a higher chance of survival. This principle is essential for effective disaster management where resources are constrained.

First come first treated basis (option A): This is incorrect as triage does not follow a "first come, first treated" approach. Instead, treatment is prioritised based on the severity of injuries and the likelihood of survival, not the order of arrival.

Green labels are for those who need to be transported on priority (option B): This is incorrect because green labels are used for patients with minor injuries (i.e., "walking wounded") who do not require urgent treatment or transportation.

Most commonly used system is three colour code system (option D): This is incorrect as the most commonly used system in disaster triage is the four-colour code system:

  • Red: Immediate care required (life-threatening but treatable injuries).
  • Yellow: Delayed care (serious but not immediately life-threatening injuries).
  • Green: Minor injuries (can wait for treatment).
  • Black: Deceased or moribund (lowest priority).

Learning Objective:

Triage:

During a disaster, the quantity and severity of injuries overwhelm the operative capacity of the health facilities. Triage involves rapidly organizing the injured individuals based on the severity of their injuries and survival with prompt interventions.

During triage, tagging should be done to each individual, including:

  1. Name
  2. Age
  3. Place of origin
  4. Triage category
  5. Diagnosis and
  6. Initial treatment.

Types of triage:

  • Reverse triage:
    • Used in surges (bed scarcity) and during wars.
    • Priority: Green→Yellow→Red.
  • Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment (START):
    • Done in remote or inaccessible areas.
    • Laymen can start doing triage before rescue teams reach.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7472824/

questions.text: What should be the minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines?
questions.solution:
• The minimum interval between two live vaccines is 4 weeks
  • Live vaccines contain weakened forms of infectious agents
  • Stimulates the immune system without causing full-blown illness
  • Interval ensures adequate immune response, minimizes interference

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of experimental study -
A. Blinding
B. Randomization
C. Defining inclusion and exclusion criteria
D. Statistical analysis
questions.solution:
Defining inclusion and exclusion criteria (Step C)

  • Establishes the study population by selecting appropriate participants.

Randomization (Step B)

  • Assigns participants into different groups (e.g., treatment vs. control) to reduce bias.

Blinding (Step A)

  • Ensures that patients, investigators, or data analysts are unaware of group assignments to prevent bias.

Statistical analysis (Step D)

  • After data collection, statistical tests are applied to determine the significance of results.

Therefore, C → B → A → D

(Defining criteria → Randomization → Blinding → Statistical analysis)

This sequence ensures a methodologically sound experimental study that minimizes bias and improves validity.

Steps in an Experimental Study

Experimental studies, such as randomized controlled trials (RCTs), follow a structured process to ensure validity and minimize bias.


B → C → A → D: Incorrect because randomization cannot occur before defining the study population.

A → B → C → D: Incorrect because blinding happens after randomization and selection of participants.

C → A → B → D: Incorrect because randomization must occur before blinding to ensure unbiased group assignment

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9469750/

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is not recommended after 65 years?
questions.solution:
• HPV vaccine is not routinely recommended after 26 years and is generally not given after 45 years, as older individuals are less likely to benefit.
  • Influenza, Pneumococcal, and Herpes Zoster vaccines are strongly recommended for adults ≥65 years to prevent severe infections.
  • HPV vaccination is primarily for younger individuals to prevent cervical and other HPV-related cancers.
  • Older adults have likely been exposed to HPV already, reducing vaccine efficacy.

Adult Vaccination Recommendations (≥65 Years)

Aging individuals face an increased risk of respiratory infections, viral reactivation, and opportunistic infections due to immune decline. Vaccination is a critical preventive strategy.


Why is the HPV Vaccine Not Given After 65?

  • Most individuals are already exposed to HPV by this age.
  • Vaccine efficacy is highest in younger populations (9-26 years).
  • No added benefit in older adults, as HPV-related cancer risk decreases.

Influenza (Option A): Incorrect because annual flu vaccination is recommended to prevent severe complications.

Herpes Zoster (Option B): Incorrect because shingles risk increases with age, so vaccination is advised after 50 years.

Pneumococcal (Option C): Incorrect because pneumococcal vaccine is recommended after 65 years to prevent pneumonia and invasive infections.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4928529/
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4928530/

questions.text: Which is not a part of Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme?
questions.solution:
he Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) Programme is structured around six key components:

  • 6 Beneficiaries- Target groups include children, adolescents, pregnant and lactating women, and women of reproductive age.
  • 6 Interventions- Includes iron supplementation, deworming, BCC (Behavior Change Communication), dietary diversification, testing, and treatment.
  • 6 Institutional Mechanisms- Ensures effective program implementation through policies, supply chain management, training, etc.
  • However, there is no mention of "6 health functionaries" in the official framework, making it the incorrect option.

6 Beneficiaries (Option A): Correct because AMB targets 6 specific groups.

6 Interventions (Option B): Correct as AMB includes 6 strategies to combat anemia.

6 Institutional Mechanisms (Option C): Correct since it ensures the smooth implementation of AMB.

Reference:

  1. https://nhm.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=3&sublinkid=1448&lid=797
  2. https://pmposhan.education.gov.in/aboutus.html
  3. https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/5x5_matrix_2502.pdf
  4. https://wcd.nic.in/kishori-shakti-yojana

questions.text: Match the following columns on Epidemiology Guidelines:
questions.solution:
CARE:

  • Stands for Case Report.
  • It is a guideline that provides a framework for reporting case reports in medical and health-related fields.
  • Case reports describe and analyze individual cases or small groups of cases, providing valuable insights into rare diseases, unusual presentations of common diseases, and unexpected treatment outcomes.

CONSORT:

  • Stands for Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials.
  • It is a guideline designed to improve the transparency and reporting of randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
  • It provides a checklist and flow diagram to ensure that essential information about the design, conduct, analysis, and interpretation of RCTs is reported in a standardised and comprehensive manner.

PRISMA:

  • Stands for Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses. It is a guideline that aims to improve the transparency and reporting of systematic reviews and meta-analyses.
  • PRISMA provides a checklist and flow diagram to ensure that researchers accurately report their systematic reviews and meta-analyses' methods, results, and interpretations.

STROBE/MOOSE:

  • STROBE stands for Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology, while MOOSE stands for Meta-analysis of Observational Studies in Epidemiology.
  • These guidelines provide recommendations for reporting observational studies, including cohort, case-control, and cross-sectional studies.
  • STROBE and MOOSE guidelines help researchers ensure that they report relevant information about the design, conduct, analysis, and interpretation of observational studies, thus enhancing the transparency and reproducibility of their findings.

Reference:

  1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_controlled_trial
  2. https://systematicreviewsjournal.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13643-021-01626-4
  3. https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamasurgery/article-abstract/2778476
  4. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28529185/

questions.text:
In biostatistics, formula given below stands for?

(σ) = √ [Σ(x - μ)² /N]
questions.solution:
• The standard deviation is a measure of the dispersion or variability of a set of values.
  • It quantifies how much the values deviate from the mean. The formula for calculating the standard deviation involves taking the square root of the average of the squared differences between each value and the mean.
  • Standard deviation is considered the most comprehensive and widely used measure of dispersion in statistical analysis.

Sample Mean (Option C): The sample mean is the average value of a set of observations or data points. It is calculated by summing all the values in the sample and dividing the total by the number of observations. The sample mean is often used as an estimate of the population mean.

Median (Option D): It is calculated by arranging the variables in ascending order and taking up the middle value.

This applies when an odd number of variables are given, which is given by


The median is given for variables in even numbers by averaging the two middle variables.

questions.text: Match the following diseases with their respective incubation period:
Match the following columns
questions.solution:
• Silicosis: Often occurs in workers exposed to silica dust in industries like mining and quarrying.
  • Asbestosis: Typically found in workers who handle asbestos, prevalent in construction and shipbuilding industries.
  • Byssinosis: Common among workers exposed to cotton, flax, or hemp dust, primarily in the textile manufacturing industry.
  • Bagassosis: an occupational lung disease caused by inhaling bagasse (sugarcane dust) in workers at a sugarcane processing plant (Causative Agent: Thermoactinomyces sacchari)

questions.text:
Water from a broken septic tank is collected in a container and breeding mosquitoes are seen. The image of the larva is given below.


Identify the species of the mosquito.
questions.solution:
These larvae rest parallel to the water surface, and their bodies have a characteristic "arched" shape. Their siphon tube is absent, and they typically lie flat against the water surface when they feed.


Images of mosquito larvae:

choices.text: 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated
90% of cases of lung cancer are due to smoking
10% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the 90% attributable risk calculated to determine the association between smoking and lung cancer?
questions.solution:
• 90% of lung cancer cases attributed to smoking, indicated by attributable risk (AR) of 90%.
  • AR measures proportion of disease cases attributed to specific exposure or risk factors.
  • Calculated by subtracting disease incidence in non-exposed from the exposed population.
  • Helps quantify impact of exposure on disease incidence

10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking (Option A): Claims 10% of lung cancers in smokers not linked to smoking, contradicts AR.

90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated (Option B): Incorrectly states eliminating smoking eliminates 90% of lung cancer cases; AR reflects proportion attributed to smoking, not eliminability.

10% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated (Option D): Incorrectly suggests eliminating smoking eliminates only 10% of lung cancer cases; contradicts AR of 90% attributed to smoking.

questions.text:
Which of the following regarding the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) is true?

1. It is used for monitoring heat exposure of the vaccine by healthcare workers in primary healthcare.
2. It shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat.
3. It can be used to assess the potential efficacy of the vaccine
4. Calculation of the expiry date can be done using VVM.
5. The expiry date of the vaccine can be relaxed if VVM is an acceptable range.
6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine can be safely used.
questions.solution:
1. It is used for monitoring heat exposure of the vaccine by healthcare workers in primary healthcare.
    This is true. VVM is a tool used in primary healthcare to monitor the exposure of vaccines to heat during transportation and storage. It is particularly useful in areas with unreliable cold chain systems.
  2. It shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat.
    This is also true. The VVM works by showing the cumulative amount of heat the vaccine has been exposed to, indicating whether the vaccine has been subjected to conditions that might reduce its efficacy.
  3. It can be used to assess the potential efficacy of the vaccine.
    This is false. The VVM does not directly assess the efficacy of the vaccine. It only shows whether the vaccine has been exposed to heat beyond its acceptable limit, which might affect its effectiveness.
  4. Calculation of the expiry date can be done using VVM.
    This is false. The VVM does not calculate the expiry date of the vaccine. It is used to monitor heat exposure, not to predict or calculate the expiry date.
  5. The expiry date of the vaccine can be relaxed if VVM is in an acceptable range.
    This is false. The VVM cannot be used to relax the expiry date of a vaccine. If the vaccine has been exposed to temperatures beyond the recommended limit, its efficacy may be compromised regardless of its expiration date.
  6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine can be safely used.
    This is false. When the square and circle on the VVM are the same color, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to heat for too long and should not be used, as it may have lost its potency.

choices.text: Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living
Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate

questions.text: Which of the following components are included in the Human Development Index (HDI), as per the World Health Organization (WHO)?
questions.solution:
• Option A is correct, including life expectancy at birth, literacy, and standard of living.
  • Components of the Human Development Index (HDI) are defined by the UNDP.
  • Life expectancy at birth reflects overall health and mortality rates.
  • Literacy measures ability to read and write, crucial for personal and economic development.
  • Standard of living encompasses material well-being and quality of life.
  • HDI combines these factors to measure human development and well-being globally.

Incorrect Options:

Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living (Option B): Incorrectly includes life expectancy at 1 year.

Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living (Option C): Incorrectly includes infant mortality rate.

Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate (Option D): Incorrectly includes life expectancy at 1 year and infant mortality rate.

questions.text: Which data set provides the most comprehensive explanation for the variation between the highest and lowest values?
questions.solution:
The range is the simplest measure of variation in a dataset. It is calculated by subtracting the lowest value from the highest value, providing a direct measure of the spread or dispersion of the data.

  • Range = Highest value - Lowest value
  • It gives a clear indication of the overall spread of data from the minimum to the maximum.

Variance (Option A): Variance measures the average squared deviation from the mean. While it indicates the spread of data, it does not directly focus on the highest and lowest values.

Coefficient of Variation (Option B): The coefficient of variation is the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean and expresses the variability relative to the mean. It's useful for comparing relative variability but doesn't focus on the highest and lowest values.

Interquartile Range (IQR) (Option D): The IQR measures the spread of the middle 50% of the data (between the 25th and 75th percentiles). While it indicates the dispersion of the central portion of the data, it does not address the variation between the highest and lowest values as directly as the range.

choices.text: Sensitivity will decrease, and specificity will increase
Sensitivity will increase, and specificity will decrease

questions.text: A large number of tests were done in series. Which of the following will be true?
questions.solution: When multiple tests are done in series, the sensitivity decreases and specificity increases.
